text: what’s the difference between calling `broadcast(f, x)` and `f.(x)`? I have the feeling it has to do with whether a certain broadcaststyle is applied, but I can’t find it in the docs.

No real difference, it seems
```julia> Meta.@lower f.(x)
:($(Expr(:thunk, CodeInfo(
    @ none within `top-level scope'
1 ─ %1 = Base.broadcasted(f, x)
│   %2 = Base.materialize(%1)
└──      return %2```
`@less broadcast(identity, [1,2])`  shows
```roadcast(f::Tf, As...) where {Tf} = materialize(broadcasted(f, As...))```

It’s just fun, Tim Poisot send me this for his package
```julia
julia> m = SimpleSDMResponse(rand(Float64, 5, 5))
SDM response → 5×5 grid with 25 Float64-valued cells
Latitudes       (-72.0, 72.0)
Longitudes      (-144.0, 144.0)

julia> broadcast(x->2x, m)
SDM response → 5×5 grid with 25 Float64-valued cells
Latitudes       (-72.0, 72.0)
Longitudes      (-144.0, 144.0)

julia> (x->2x).(m)
25-element Array{Float64,1}:
0.22642692199451053
1.567732933396191
0.006969107295966115
0.9455406546708978
0.2365786744299565```
And I thought this might be because he’s defined `getindex` for the type but not `broadcaststyle`?
